Award.AwardTitle: Reverse Transcriptase-Related Genes and Their Biological Significance

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Reverse transcriptases are enzymes that perform DNA synthesis on RNA templates. It is widely believed that reverse transcriptase activity is mostly used by selfish genetic elements, such as retrotransposons and retroviruses, for their own replication and propagation. The only known exceptions are telomerases, which are encoded by single-copy genes and maintain eukaryotic chromosome ends by repeatedly copying a small region of the associated RNA template onto DNA. This project seeks to understand the evolutionary origins and cellular functions of RNA-dependent polymerization by studying novel reverse transcriptase-related genes found in diverse eukaryotes, using computational, biochemical, and genetic approaches. Phylogenetic distribution and relationships with other classes of reverse transcriptases, enzymatic activity of the encoded products, and possible involvement in cellular pathways will be investigated. These studies could reveal previously unknown roles for RNA-dependent polymerization in living cells. Elucidation of evolutionary origins and cellular functions of reverse transcriptase-related genes is of fundamental importance and may be expected to have a major impact on the fields of molecular biology, genetics, and evolution.

Broader Impacts: The project will have both scientific and educational impacts. The results of the study are expected to challenge the currently established views on the role of RNA-dependent polymerization, which may be significantly under-appreciated. Educational activities will include training of graduate and undergraduate students and their direct involvement in research, which will result in student-coauthored publications. Other activities will include: active participation in national and international scientific meetings to ensure broader dissemination of the results to members of the scientific community; organization of regional meetings to provide venues for information exchange and training and, through travel grants, to attract minority participants; and active involvement in science fairs at local high schools. Outreach efforts will be aimed at bringing results of NSF-funded research to non-specialists and the general public through media interviews and contributions to popular books targeted at wider audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: Since their discovery in viruses more than 40 years ago, reverse transcriptases, enzymes that perform DNA synthesis on RNA templates, remain the most enigmatic enzymes among all known polymerases. Although they are widely used in molecular biology and biotechnology to convert genetic information from RNA back into DNA, in most cases these enzymes belong to selfish mobile genetic elements, which employ it for their own replication and propagation. Only one type of reverse transcriptase, called telomerase, was domesticated by ancestral eukaryotes to extend the ends of linear chromosomes by repeatedly copying a specialized RNA onto the termini. We have discovered another type of reverse transcriptase-related genes recruited from mobile genetic elements and present across different domains of Life, including not only eukaryotes but certain bacteria. For a detailed characterization, we chose representatives from highly diverse groups: invertebrate animals (rotifers), filamentous fungi (bread molds), and filamentous gliding bacteria (see images). We showed that each group codes for an active enzyme, existing in a multimeric form. Molecular dissection revealed different domains of the protein responsible for multimer formation and for initiation of polymerization. An inventory of similar proteins across kingdoms and domains of life revealed their evolutionary connections and patchy distribution across phyla. Our studies also revealed that in some cases these genes may still be recognized as foreign by the small RNA-based defense machinery of the host, a study designated as one of the spotlights of the year by the Genetics Society of America. In total, five original research articles and four reviews were published in peer-reviewed international journals.  

Broader impacts: Two postdoctoral scholars received training under this grant. Integration of research and education was achieved by training graduate and undergraduate students while directly involving them in research during summer internships. In two of the original papers, students were included as co-authors. Other activities included active participation in national and international scientific meetings, to ensure broader dissemination of the results to members of the scientific community, and organization of bi-annual regional meetings which served as information exchange and training venues and attracted minority participants through travel awards. Outreach efforts aimed at bringing results of NSF-funded research to non-specialists and the public included media interviews and the release of visually arresting photomicrographs of rotifers, fungi and bacteria (see images) into the public domain as award-winning photo entries (NSF Visualization Challenge; Olympus; Nikon), peer-reviewed images (Cell Image Library), and journal covers (Life Sciences Education).
